reviewText:
xeno- prefix. from Ancient Greek ξένος (ksénos, “alien”) a. Having to do with foreigners, as in xenophilia, or more commonly, xenophobia. b. From a foreign place, as in xenolith.

clash noun. onomatopoeic a. A skirmish, a hostile encounter. b. Opposition, contradiction, such as between differing or contending interests, views, purposes etc.

In my imagination, the development of Xeno-- sorry, Zeno Clash -- started when folks at Ace Team got together, got high, and got onto the subject of ancient mythologies (Roman, Greek, Norse, etc.) and how weird they all were. I mean, if you want crazy characters and crazier stories, you need look no further than some of the gods and goddesses traipsing around back in the day. Athena, birthed fully formed out of the sweaty forehead of Zeus; Pan, the goat-god of wanton sex; Artemis, goddess of the hunt, who for some reason was depicted in various interpretations as being literally covered with breasts; Medusa, she of the stylish snake perm and stony gaze, being some kind of metaphor for psychosexual wackiness (I'm pretty sure we can blame Freud for that); Jeff, the God of Biscuits; and even some nutter who told people to eat some bread and drink some wine and pretend it was his flesh and his blood... I mean, ew, dude. I'm sure we have enough problems without adding cannibalism to it. So anyway, the developers were shooting the breeze about Gods and Golden Fleece and rivers of blood and whatever until one guy, as I imagine it, stood up and went, Yeah... but like
date: what if... Dude! What if there were

commentsCount: THEY also had myths and ♥♥♥♥! I mean... dude..."\n\nSo that's where this game comes from

reviewText:
+ Combat system is incredibly simple and satisfying; everything connects and feels right, making this the game's greatest strength
+ Character designs are creative and interesting; just the right mixture of weird and entertaining
+ Strange weapon designs; very original in every respect (if you've seen the 1999 film ExistenZ, imagine the chicken bone gun, and populate an entire game-world with the same concept)
+ Control scheme is efficient, and every button-press felt natural and satisfying
+ Strange, yet appropriate soundtrack; did well to set the mood and keep you feeling mildly unsettled
+ Atmospheric elements worked well with the environmental set-pieces to make for an absolutely bizarre world; I must say that this level of creativity, while unconventional, was a breath of fresh air
+ Challenging, adaptive AI; enemies really keep you on your toes in the best possible way (save for a few, minor shortcomings - some of the bosses are also a bit too easy to cheese)

- Terrible voice-acting
- Stiff, clumsy animations
- Frustrating and unnecessary lock-on system
- Save for a (rather dull) Challenge Mode, and the ability to unlock cheat codes for the campaign, this title has virtually no replay value
- Largely weak sound effects
- Poorly explained, muddled plot with little character development and too many answers left out (topped off with a mediocre cliffhanger)

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Also, feel free to join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements. Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
Truly a masterpiece. Fight your way to the truth of an unhinged world through mobsters, monsters, deranged beings and dark creatures.
Zenozoik is a wonderful, vivid world, but this is no paradise. Forget the tales about the 'good savage', for this land is full of secrets and violence. Find out the reason of the brutal hunting you suffer from your own brothers, the secret crimes Ghat has come to know. In this first journey in Zenozoik, there'll be some revelations, but also questions that'll make you wish everything hidden to be brought into the open.
The world ACE Team has created is really unique, and you'll always feel that there's much more to see... and to fight. Because Zeno Clash is above all, a brawling game, and it excels on it. The extraordinary plot backs an addictive and satisfying combat system, and luckyly the game includes modes beyond the main history which will sate your thirst for beating throwing you right into the action, in the increasingly harder stages of a tower which progressive destruction will delight you by its smart use of physics.
Zeno Clash is an indispensable, which will remind you why some games deserve to be considered art; exalted visuals, surprising lore and relentless fights await you. Welcome to Zenozoik, brother.

reviewText:
I had no idea what the hell I was doing, but I beat it, somehow.

It's relatively short, but the world is alien in both a good and a bad way. Some of the designs are awesome, funny and nice, others are just plain ugly and it doesn't always fit together. But I guess that's what makes Zeno Clash the game it is: Awkward and fun, much less than it could have been. An incredibly inventive universe only lightly touched by it's weird little storyline.

I recommend Zeno Clash for anyone looking for an intriguing brief experience, or people with a thing for tattoo'd on moustaches.

reviewText:
8/10

Strong fantasy appeal.  The world and story is of new mythology.  Fighting system is challenging, fun, annoying, and very immersive.  For the most part the game is moderate difficulty from beginning to end.  Some of the fights can be easily beaten once you find a weakness in the A.I. or level design.  The game favors freaks who love originality.  The short length was perfect for the story.  Because it is a short game I would reccomend getting it on sale.  Overall a very enjoyable experience.  I have gained a number of concepts and ideas that will occupy my daydreams for the next month or so. I will be getting Zeno Clash 2 next time it is on sale.

[If you are having problems with the fighting system then wait a few months and come back to it.  Start the game over and try again.  Worked for me.]

reviewText:
TL:DR? See Conclusion
INTRODUCTION:Zeno Clash is a first-person melee fighting game developed by ACE Team using Valve's famous Source Engine and released on Steam back in 2009.

The story begins with Ghat, the game's protagonist, waking up after being knocked out by an explosion which killed a creature known as Father-Mother who is the leader of a very powerful mafia like family in the small town of Halstedom. The protagonist Ghat is presumably one of Father-Mother's children who turned rogue and ran away from home and is now being pursued by his 'brothers and sisters' (enforcers of Father-Mother). Join him and his companion Deadra in a quest to discover the truth of about Ghat's past and trace back the series of events that led to the explosion.

PROS:+ Excellent use of the Source Engine
+ Good fisticuffs (melee) combat mechanic
+ Surreal world and environment
+ Complex but enjoyable story
+ Interesting character, item and monster designs
+ Item variety
+ Good sound effects and voice acting
+ The Devs were probably high during this game's production
+ Challenging difficulties

CONS:- Extremely short (4-5 hours game time in my last playthrough)
- Almost no replay value (except for the tower challenge mode)
- Difficult learning curve
- Story is a bit difficult to follow
- Short linear levels (In my opinion, linear games are fine as long as the levels are lengthy and enjoyable)
- No character progression (no armors, level ups or item upgrades)

CONCLUSION:GOOD GAME. Zeno Clash sports a very unique art style that places you in a very surreal world with a strange geography and is populated by strange creatures all brought to life by the developer's clever use of Valve's Source Engine. The combat mechanics is fun albeit a little frustrating at times and hard to learn however, the items does give variety to the player's fighting style. The game should provide you with at least 4-5 hours of game time with its campaign with an added 'Tower Challenge' if the player wants to test his skills.

I RECOMMEND this game mostly for the experience but the short game time could be an issue, still though, Zeno Clash is a fun game to play. I can't honestly cannot recommend it at full price (even if it is only $10 or your regional equivalent), so getting it on a sale is probably a better idea.

reviewText: Very strange, to be honest, I thought someone dosed me with something, I had to ask and confirm with other people that this game was real. The gameplay at its heart is a first person brawler, with a healthy mix up of shooting here and there. but the story, woa ho ho.... man. imagine a world that was generations deep with inbreeding, as well as cross breeding with chickens and pigs, and not the cute jrpg way, but more of a demented master blaster way. This is the world you're going to get into with this game.\n\nI did not like the melee combat at first, but the story kept me playing, and I ended up finding that the parry hit and run knee to the face smash tactics to be, well....... really good. and by the end of the game I found myself actually wanting to toss my guns down and put my fists up. It's short, but left me satisfied. I hope we see more of this twisted world.

reviewText:
Zeno clash is probably one of the more memorable games I've played this year. Set in one of the most creative worlds I have ever witnessed, this game stands out as a real gem to me.

+Well-developed melee fighting where you can lash together combos, strike quickly or strongly, or pick a median attack. Blocking, dodging, countering, finishing. Many great moves to help you deal with the situation at hand.
+Ranged weapons that work fairly well from dual-wielded pistols, rifles, crossbows, or 'grenade launchers'. All very imaginatively designed in a way that they're nothing like you'd imagine based upon how I just described them. Unfortunately they make some fights a little too easy, but without them those same fights would have been a bit too hard.
+It's challenging, but not unfair. Many games today are either too easy, or designed unfairly to promote difficulty. Zeno clash is almost the perfect median between the two.
+The voice acting for the characters is simply splended. Every voice actor was given strange roles to fit, very specific roles, and they all nailed them with excellence.
+Great and memorable characters. From the moral-less Ghat, to the kind and caring Deadra, to the mysterious Father-Mother and all of his-her sons and daughters you face throughout the game. To the also-mysterious Golem, and even to the many unique Corwid you face throughout the game. Oxameter and Gabel being the most memorable.
+The story is confusing to begin with, but as you progress and learn more about what's happening it is fantastic. Absolutely great. Unfortunately it ends in a bit of a cliff hanger but that's fine! We have a sequel available to us!
+The world is simply stunning. The setting is so unique and refreshing, I just want to experience more and more of it. Give me more!
+The music fits the game so well! Matching every moment almost perfectly! Well-arranged tracks as well.
+A challenge mode to keep you entertained after you beat the main story, which is well needed since....
-I finished the game in a little over 3 hours. And the challenge mode will keep you busy for about one extra hour, which is nice.

I give this game a solid 9/10. How short it is is what holds it back from its full potential, but this is a game no one should miss. Definitely pick this one up as soon as possible!

reviewText:
Zeno Clash is a wierd game that tries to, and succeeds at, doing something that no other FPS has done.  The story is strange, the characters are mysterious, and the player is left continuously wondering what will happen next.  Unfortunately, the story is also not interesting. The game just throws disparate scenario after scenario at you presented as a series of events that happened before the beginning of the game, and it leaves it largely up to you to connect these events.  The characters are not expanded upon, the enemies are only briefly expounded on, and the main characters motivations are left entirely unclear.  I believe this was a choice made deliberately to add mystery to the story, but for me it only left me wanting for a clear reason to continue to my goal.
None of this would be a problem if the game was fun.  I don't need a reason to complete the game if I enjoy playing it.  Zeno Clash is unique in that it tries to blend melee and ranged combat in an FPS in a way I've never seen before.  The melee portion includes blocking, counter attacks, dodging, grabs, and other staples of good melee combat.  The mechanics of the game is what brings it down in this respect.  It would take a long time to describe exactly how frustrating it is to control the combat, but I frequently ended up performing the wrong defensive move which would result in my taking damage.  Furthermore, the counterattacks don't work.  Almost every time I tried to counter an enemy they would block or dodge my counterattack.
The ranged combat has similar problems.  Guns are not meant to be used exclusively.  You are supposed to pick up a weapon and shoot an enemy as many times as you can until they get close to you.  This part feels good.  Watching an enemy running towards you, it feels great to score those two big hits that send them flying on their back then pelting them with more shots until they start towards you again.  When they start getting closer though is when the frustration begins.  When an enemy gets close, you are meant to lock on to put away your weapon and begin melee.  However, running away from an enemy breaks your lock, so if you are trying to get away, the gun comes back out.  If you are hit with the gun out, it drops to the ground with whatever ammo it had, where enemies can pick it up and use it against you.  In short, again, the mechanincs of this game make it very frustrating to do what you want to do, and to fight multiple enemies.
In conclusion, I wanted to like this game.  I like wierd games, I like difficult games, and I like story-driven games.  I HATE frustrating games, however, and this falls squarely into that last category.  The mechanincs of combat don't work, the story was not holding my interest, and I felt no reason to complete the game.  In addition, I found a Zeno Clash process running in the background of my PC even though I hadn't played the game in days and the game itself was not running, so my hours played are inflated.  I should note I did not finish this game.

reviewText: Zeno Clash is a very strange game with a great atmosphere. It's hard to describe how the game presents itself; you'll have to see it to understand it. Because of its modest price tag, this is definitely worth checking out for everyone who appreciates an action packed and strange experience or someone who is looking for something original. It's only a shame it's such a short experience.You'll either love it or hate it. If you can let the bizarre world and characters entice you, you will get your money's worth. Its flawed gameplay will annoy most people though. If you're open-minded, you might appreciate this unique experience.Zeno Clash is a marvel, channeling yesterday’s hardcore brawlers whilst maintaining modern sensibilities.Zeno Clash demonstrates why often the most Bizarre projects can only be developed by independent companies. No “major” could ever do something like this, and that’s because we are talking about one of the most suggestive and atypical titles of recent times.Despite the initial weirdness and a few flaws, Zeno Clash is a unique take on first-person fighting that anyone with an open mind will likely enjoy.Overall 7/10.

reviewText:
What the heck is Zeno Clash?

Zeno clash is a first person bang em up type game where the player can punch or kick the crap out of his opponents. Seems like simple fun arcade stuff right? Sort of is, but there are added features to the game (beside the campaign) that make it significant.

The storyline is a good one to say the least. There is a guy who trains you in the game and by the time he's done training you, he simply kills himself. This game is whacky, weird, and odd, but how it all comes together within the world is awesome. When people speak about creative games, this one definitely takes the cake with it's outrageous characters. Besides the game play, the characters alone will make you double take. They are given personalities with extreme oddity that simply makes it appealing. I fought a boss who jumped on top of a bunch of dinosaurs while trying to kill me for pete's sake. I really like the fighting engine and the added features of being able to pick up guns, crossbows, and other sort of crazy weaponry like blunt objects that send opponents flying. When you fight, it actually feels like you're making contact with the opponent. The feedback in the punches was done phenomenally.

Should you buy it? On sale I would say unless you REALLY like these types of games.

For future Zeno Clash games I would recommend multiplayer, and maybe even dare to try to incorporate local co-op. To add to the fighting, perhaps add kicks or even allow for players to hold down the mouse button, then use the mouse to swing to determine the type of swing. Don't make it to the point where people start snapping their mouse cord, but something decently close enough.

8.2/10

get's an extra .2 for being a breakaway new type of genre.
voteText: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If there ever was an award for weirdest world, Zeno Clash would be a top contender. The game starts with you killing your Father-Mother(Which is a single entity) under suspicious circumstances and it doesn't slow down from there as you progress both further away, running from your brothers and sisters, and back to the start, through flashbacks explaining how you came to kill your Father-Mother. At no point does Zeno Clash attempt to make excuses for it's insane universe, no explanation is given for anything that does not fit within the games context, things simply are.

Some will love this and some will hate it but either way you can't help but admire the writers for making such an uncompromising world that gives you one WTF? moment after the other with barely a second to catch your breath.

The gameplay is simplistic repetitive beat-em-up not worth mentioning but the game should be played, if only to experience the madding world of Zeno Clash, whose like you won't find anywhere else.

reviewText: Would you like a game that's really simple yet solid, like the beat'em ups from the days of yore (but in first person view)? What about an art style that looks like the lovechild of Roger Dean and David Cronenberg on acid? A soundtrack with a wild sense of urgency? Do you want to feel like Kenshiro from Hokuto no Ken, punching people into the air, while the story discreetly discusses  Sartrean Existentialism and Hobbesian societal notions? Do you want to shoot multibreasted rat people with a fishgun? What about birdmen? Then this game is for you!!!!!

reviewText:
A short, but action packed journey in a unique world.

You are on the run, hunted by your own family for the murder of your own father - or better - Father-Mother, aided only by the young woman by your side.
The story is split in two parallel storylines: your present and your past, which will unfold via flashbacks, as you narrate your past and motives to your only remaining friend, and will take you to the very end of the world, before you decide to return home to settle your past once and for all.

Gameplay-wise, the combat in this game is praised as one of the best melee combat experiences in gaming, and while I don't fully agree, I certainly see how it may be so for many people.
You will find an immersive first person combat system, where every punch and every block counts, and mostly, FEELS right.

In the end, it is a short story of ideals and revelations that may even manage to make you think of society as we see it.

Hard to recommend to everyone, although it is so short (I completed it in 5h and I'm sure it can be completed in a little less) that even those who simply seek an alternative adventure won't be too weighed down.

I do recommend it, however, to first person brawlers' fans, you will be given every tool to test your fighting skills.

In short: short, first person brawler with excellent, fleshed out combat and a story with a morale set in a bizarre world.

reviewText: I mainly knew about ACE team because of the incredibly impressive Batman Doom, but I was surprised they were a commercial studio. I was definitely not disappointed in their first commercial effort. Simple, effective gameplay and visuals that feel straight out of Heavy Metal. First person brawlers need a much bigger presence. I've played an hour and a half but I'm halfway through the game. The simplicity makes up for the length though, and it feels like it can offer more replay in return. Don't bother complaining about it, you probably have more games in your Steam account than you can finish in your lifetime anyways. Be thankful you're not getting a 50 hour timesink that you'll put off playing forever because of the daunting length.

I'm going to give the controversial opinion and say that I didn't really enjoy this game.

The first person combat is amazing, yes. I love the way that the first person fighting mechanics feel. But the story just could not hold my interest.

The world you are put in is such an interesting and creative one, yet the plot is so jointed and disconnected that I never felt like I got to know the world very well. The story and plot was just too confusing for me to understand. Many aspects just felt unexplained, and the game ends on a sequel hook cliffhanger.

Is the game worth trying? Sure. But personally? I felt the confusing story made the game drag on far too long.

reviewText:
First person games with good melee combat are sadly rare.  Too often it basically consists of flailing your arms with no force feedback until the enemy falls over (see Elder Scrolls).  Which is a a shame, because when these types of games do show up, they tend to be pretty awesome.
As you can guess, Zeno Clash has good melee combat.  It's fairly simple, but it feels good.  You can dodge and block, punch and throw to your heart's content.  My only real complaint about the combat is that at times it feels a little barebones, especially because the game doesn't force you into most advanced techniques.  I rarely dodged or blocked in my playthrough (although I have yet to do the tower challenges).
The melee segments are broken up by time with various other weapons, and a few boss battles.  I often found myself wishing I could go back to the melee combat (especially during the repetitive fights with heavy enemies), but even these segments were mildly enjoyable at worst and fun at best.
The game also has a pretty good story.  It's simple and short, but it's supported by a wonderfully strange world, and it's fairly engaging.  It ends poorly though, with barely any sense of conclusion.  The game ends up feeling like a prologue for the sequel.

All in all it's a very solid game.  Good melee combat, great world, fun variety of segments.  It's definitely not perfect: It's very short, and it's basically a series of scenes with fades between so it feels at times disjointed and restricting, but it's an enjoyable game, and worth playing if you like unique games or just want to beat up a bunch of weird creatures.
voteText: 11 of 18 people (61%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
'Zeno Clash' is a debut game by ACE Team, who are the developers who recently released 'Rock of Ages'.

This is an impressive title. Extraordinarily impressive. An FPS focusing mostly on brawling and few weapon mechanics, the gameplay is not only innovative, but stunningly creative and chocked full of potential. The imagination used to create this game is off the charts: it's a cornucopia of color and design. ACE has left no stone unturned when  creating an entirely new world. Not only do they focus on the visuals of the planet but also the unique culture, technology, wildlife, language and the natives that inhabit this strange new land. When it comes to being engulfed in a whole new reality, I've seen few games do it as seamlessly as 'Zeno Clash'.

While the gameplay is unvaried and by no means perfect, this reasonably short foray leaves you wanting MORE. For 'Zeno Clash', this is a good thing. This is one game that will have you chomping at the bit for a sequel.

reviewText: Both a solid first-person beat 'em up and containing some of the most fantastically bizarre and cool artwork akin to something like Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee, Zeno Clash is a pretty short game but well worth it for the fun gameplay, excellent character designs and environments and unique plotline.

reviewText:
absurdism is difficult. that which is otherworldly, that which is abstract understanding, can only stem from relations of relations of corrupted understandings. people gravitate toward things far removed from understanding. people talk and caw about games having disparate worlds, but zeno clash is true. zeno clash features a world so far removed from anything in fiction or in living. its an absolute triumph of visual direction. zeno clash is a textbook on the deranged. with all of my praise though, it does remind one distinctly of oddworld. however, zeno clash’s world is much more lively - less barren to say - and there are many humans. though there are many other creatures as well.

whatever zeno clash ended up looking like, the base idea is something I would sell myself off for. I am incredibly glad this game exists. beat ‘em ups are eternal for me. what rings incredibly true for zeno clash is how traditional it is. you fight with two kinds of punches, light and heavy. a light punch can strike up to three times and can be comboed into a strong. strong punches are kind of like a wind up punch; space yourself away from your target and dash in with your fist. both are incredibly satisfying thanks to impeccable animation and hit detection. if an enemy becomes dazed, they can be thrown. and that’s basically it. the basic tendency calls back the roots of the beat ‘em up genre, a very comfortable thing for me, and a very different trace of influence for a modern game. especially considering the direction beat ‘em ups have taken with devil may cry, ninja gaiden, and god of war - although those are fantastic titles - it’s nice to see a game toning things back. except, I’d probably enjoy a hyper-complex combat system more, in all honesty.

if zeno clashed revolved around limited arena battles punching the trash out of fugly foes, and in saying that it does anyway, then it’d be a fantastic game that anyone looking for new ideas in their vidcons should play. it wouldn’t raise any intellectual hell, but exist as something more primal than serious sam, with an even goofier atmosphere. the boxing arenas are still totally worth it. but what was a successful formula gets bogged down by forced variance. ace team wasn’t content with the gold they struck - or maybe the gold was struck from altering their original first person shooter formula? either way, there are guns in the game. shoehorned guns. guns that are not fun to shoot or use. if they were options to use in the battle royals then they would be tarnishing, but forgivable. they are not. the gunplay is forced numerous times. thankfully they are not long, yet the damage is still felt. it’s not like anything is broken with the guns - it’s just they’re incredibly mediocre compared to your fists. the endworld is an exception to that with interesting and fun ranged combat. though pacing of using a magic wand leaves some to be desired and the enemies you fight are nothing more than zombies, it’s still darkly enchanting.

ranged weapons present one problem and melee weapons present another. melee weapons have a light swing and a heavy swing, much like your hands. once again, they function like they always have in the genre. they’re usually satisfying to use and offer a break from cracking skulls with your knuckles all day. the problem isn’t in the melee weapons, but when you’re given them. not too often can you use them against normal facepunchers. heavyweight enemies can only be damaged and toppled by heavy weapons and only the charge attack really does any damage. this leads to very mediocre and unsatisfying fights. there are no gambits allowed, no subcombos to pull off, no variety to speak of. you distance yourself, wind up attack, strafe, bash, retreat, repeat. and zeno clash will just throw these fatties at you as the game progresses. they’ll be one with small guys, one coming right after another, and at one point in the game two at a time. the two at a time encounter is pretty damn cool honestly. still, they are static and unfun encounters, and drag down what should be the pinnacle of the game.

if zeno clash had a more organic presentation it would be legendary. if you traversed large and odd levels, fisting waves of enemies, it would have ascended. even if it had rather linear levels with stop and fight sequences, it still would have delivered a wholly amazing game. instead you’re more often that not pitted in smallish arenas to fight your rounds. there are more traditional fps orientated levels to be found, but in those you do not punch, which is all the more confusing. levels are relegated to being plot excerpts filled with gameplay, instead of having the plot compliment the gameplay. its pacing is haphazard and disappointing. it wants to have this grand adventure and yet its levels are arcade in nature. not like double dragon arcade, but dig-dug. they’re just rounds. that feeling is even more horribly accented in the second half when you repeat most of the places you already walked through on your return trip home, just with harder enemies.

sheer repetition is zeno clash’s greatest flaw. guns are no different from eachother besides how many bullets sit in the chamber. melee weapons offer no variation aside from different looking skins. both guns and weapons have wonderful models, but that’s not the kind of variation I’m vying for. there are many different and awesome looking enemies. those many different awesome looking enemies will be fought two to even three times each. their names are the same, I guess they are the same people, but when you fight the same enemies in the same level as a few hours before it feels really freaking lazy. with the two bounty hunter confrontations, both very great despite relying on poor gunplay, it’s more than obvious that ace team really wanted variation in their game. so the design choices in the meat of their game sit in ugly defiance to their vision. a real frustrating execution overall.

writing is stilted. purposefully, the characters need to assume their roles as midsavages. there is a mighty depth and conviction to the script. made up words and made up accents. though, the voice acting does not match the quality of writing, and is rather poor. the story itself, framed as a mystery, compliments the game’s piecemeal length. when it’s all said and done though the plot is a bit flat. it’s not really about what ghat did so much as ghat dealing with why he did it. with the characters being in a generally unrelatable state of mind, the implications aren’t so interesting to learn about. what’s great about the script is the weird things, the corwids, father-mother’s society, the endworld, golem’s crypticness. these things really draw you in. it succeds in vision and skill of writing even if it does not have the running time to tell a deep story.

zeno clash is an addled burst of fraught strangeness smoothed with brand new gameplay. its short length makes it very easy to recommend, but it also is its greatest limiter with unrealized ideas all over the place. zeno clash is a small game and isn’t content with it. because of that, I’m not exactly content with it either.

reviewText:
Gameplay:

You can normal punch, strong punch, block and dodge. You can also do some advanced techniques like a super strong punch, a rushed elbow hit, and if you block then press your normal punch or strong punch button you can land a devastating quick kick. It's pretty simple. There are also weapons that have a small magazine" (the best gun I found had 3 shots before I had to reload). You mostly walk in a straight line.  It is kind of dreamlike because even though it is linear many of the things from point A to B are cut out. For example in one part you are in the forest and then 5 minutes later (after a fight) you are in the coast. The gameplay is simple but fun.

Story:

Without giving too much away: Ghat murders Father-Mother (the name implies everything). He is on the run and his girlfriend (Deadra) tags along cause I don’t know. You get many flashbacks that tell more of the story and you try to piece it together. He refuses to tell his girlfriend Father-Mother's secret (why he killed it). This game is kind of weird. See a couple of the screenshots and you will see what I mean. The world looks twisted and colorful as do the characters. People are weird and some talk in riddles. You definitely will be laughing at some points in the game.

Definitely get it. The story mode is short but you also get a challenge mode. I believe there is an SDK for this game but I haven’t come across any mods."

reviewText: Zeno Clash is a First Person Brawler" by Chilean developer ACE Team. Made in the Source Engine
date: Zeno Clash is nothing but oozing in creativity. From the zany monster design to the intriguing weapons

reviewText: What a strange game this is. Zeno Clash's dialogue, artstyle, characters and environments are all unique and work well together to tell a short, but interesting story. A lot of it doesnt make any sense in the beginning, but I think that just adds to the experience. Combat is a very strong aspect in Zeno Clash. It is a first person brawler with bits of shooting thrown in. The bulk of the combat will be punching and kicking the ♥♥♥♥ out of everybody. It can get to be challenging once more enemies get in it with you. Mastering the block and parry system can be difficult, but it will definitely be rewarding, since a sucessful bloack/parry combo can send an enemy flying across the screen. Theres nothing more satisfying than being able to do that. Also, you can kick the ♥♥♥♥ out of people while theyre on the ground. That feels good too.

reviewText:
This is a first person melee brawler, which is quite a new take on the genre. The world is imaginatively designed and the music, while not particularly special is a nice mix of tribal music.

Its a short and linear adventure at around 6 hours. Gameplay is a hit and miss. When the punches connect, they feel satisfying. However, it is frustrating when hit detection goes wonky. There is also a lock-on mechanic, while useful in theory, is a hassle when you need to get away from enemies. While there are also guns, they have too little ammo and load much too slowly to be effective in combat.

The story is simple, but the way its presented is confusing and the characters aren't very memorable. The female sidekick you have doesn't help much at all in combat and would have been much better if she can be used as a co-op partner.

Overall Rating: 6.5 / 10
Not worth to buy full price, but worth a look if on sale. This is an unpolished gem and is a good first effort from this indie studio.

reviewText:
A first-person beat'em up game at it's finest! The world of Zeno Clash is very bizarre and weird which make exploring even more fun :D The main focus of the combat system are the melee fights.  It is pretty basic and not very complicated to master the melee system. You can punch, kick, throw, block, evade and deflect attacks. Combine those possibilities with the physics engine turns to be a LOT of fun!

The weapons are very easy to use. Most of them have unlimited ammo but need to be reloaded properly. If you want to put your weapon away for a melee fight, you just need to lock on" to an enemy.

The levels are pretty small but it works for this title. The only thing I didn't like it so far would be the skybox. It was pretty empty most of the time. The story is quite nice and makes you want to buy the sequel... KAK!"

reviewText:
Definitely not my thing.

The setting intrigued me initially and I love the world it's set in, but as a game, it's essentially street fighter with bird people.

That's not to say the game is bad, It's just not something I would play repeatedly.

I long ago stopped playing combat-centric games.

As this game goes, it has FANTASTIC combat.

If you like focusing on which attack to choose on a particular opponent, you will like this game. A lot.

You will like it doubly if you're into post-apocalytic dystopain sci-fi stories.

I wish they'd expounded on the world they had created more, but I highly recommend this game, despite not being a huge fan of the genre.

reviewText: While I wouldn't say that Zeno Clash was the worse game that I had ever played, I will, in no way, provide the illusion that it is anywhere within the realm of an acceptable game. Zeno Clash boasts a difficulty ramp that is unleveled and radical, in addition to a storyline that is mediocre on a good day. The gameplay, while could be improved, is admittedly quite nice, and has a nice ebb and flow to it. However, this does not mak up for it's other lacking mechanics.\n\nIn addition to all of this, for the amount it costs, it is a frustratingly short game, and lengthing it would also improve the value immensely.

reviewText:
This is a very unique expierience that stands out from most games for various reasons that i will go into. i say that this game, atleast from me, gets a 9/10. why? let's find out.

Visuals 10/10: this game's design is outlandish and surreal in almost every nook and cranny, but my oh my is it beautiful to look at. even though it does follow an invisible wall system, it feels as though you can just walk out and explore the world of zenoik. and that's just talking about it's scenery, it's characters are just as strange but fun to look at as their environment. from the corwids to the northern gate gang, there is a vibrant and bizarre variety of characters to see. and granted even though this game is considerably older than most next gen titles, it is very impressive for it's time.

Gameplay 9/10: the concept of not relying on guns or swords but entirely on your fists sounds like anybody's childhood dream. and by god is it satisfying to punch somebody's face in in this game,and this right here is what makes this game so refreshing from the other titles. and it's great to feel that sense of impact when you hit someone or throw them into another fighter, through the majority of the game you'll have to rely on that. and even though there are weapons, they are all balanced to a degree in which you should only really use them if you absolutley have to. for example the club, it causes considerable damage to fighters but will break upon constant use. the cons about this though is the fact that i wish there were more combinations and ways to inflict damage than there already are. for example maybe adding in a right punch left punch system that would allow and demand for combo moves. but overall, it is a solid gameplay system.

Story 7.5/10: this is where zeno clash starts to show some pretty bad flaws, it's story is fantastic and it's thought provoking. but it's really hard to follow sometimes and it cause alot of confusion with how fast things go by, especially the flashbacks, in which ghat explains why did what he did. but they seem to go by at the speed of sound sometimes expecting it's audience to keep up. however! it's voice acting and characterization is what saves it, you will remember who is who with their unique design and backgrounds and they will serve as reminders for later on if you happen to have forgotten what has happened. overall, it's an amazing storyline hindered by minor plotholes and really fast pacing.

Concept 10/10: probably one of the most crisp and unique designs i've seen to date. for stonepunk is not a genre you hear all too often due to it not sounding all that appealing or fun. but it is indeed a sight to behold, and what i love most about it is it's independence in character design, you could add a rock man wearing bones around him and he'd fit in just fine. and it's design may turn others away for fearful reasons even, for some of the characters do look very bizarre and for some quite hideous or terrifying. but if your tired of seeing copy and paste soldiers or sexy chicks with no other purpose than being attractive. than this is a design worth looking into.

Replayability 9/10: this is an absolute joy to play, whether your looking for overly fun gameplay or delicous eyecandy this is worth the price it has. for there are many possibilities for how you can go about fights in the second playthrough, for example you may have been beaten by jsaj over a million times due to you just starting the game but be able to be an equal or better fighter than he is on the second try due to knowing how to play better. as for the story, you can play it again and have a more clear understanding of things, but as for all story based games you will already know what will happen. so nothing will suprise you too much.

Overall: this is a diamond in the rough for video game standards, with a concept so bold that it could've really sunk all the way down to rock bottom. but it succeeds in what it tries to accomplish, bare knuckle fightin'. it almost makes me wish that there were more first person punchers out there with how well this turned out. and even though it feels as though it sacrifices a good story for better gameplay, i don't think many will complain if they just want to have fun. but in all honesty, this is a must have in my opinion for those who want to see something new and done well on their plate.

reviewText:
Zeno clash a first person shooter game set in a crazy some what cave man style world full of mystery and oddity. Sit back and gaze a pone this beautiful word while trying to not die by suicidal squirrels with bombs strapped to them.

Game Play: 8

The game play over all is a typical shooter for the most part. You get guns that you aim and shoot while running around. However this game adds in a nice elemental of first person melee combat. While this game is mostly about shooting than melee, The melee does add a nice touch to it but it also has it's own problems. While trying to melee it tends to feel off and a little clunky. However if you can get the melee down it's pretty fun. Some of the weapons you have are duel Pistols, a rifle, a crossbow, skull grenades, and more. Each has an alt fire that can be used. Pretty much like most other shooters it's mainly point and shoot not much else.

There isn't many bosses to fight in game. However this game has one of my most favorite boss fights of all time. You'll find yourself fighting a blind bounty hunter who sits on top of a dinosaur's head that is at least fifty feet above you. Who gives you a rift to make it far for you to fight him. He sits up there shooting down at you. While tossing down squirrels with bombs strapped to them to chase you around and blow up that you have to kick around and avoid. Yes... you did read that right... mother ♥♥♥♥ing squirrels with mother ♥♥♥♥ing bombs strapped to there mother ♥♥♥♥ing backs! How can you NOT like this boss fight! It is so odd but yet so much fun!

Story: 7

The story takes place in a fictional fantasy world called Zenozoik, and begins in a town called Halstedom. You play as ghat the protagonist of the game, You are running away from your home village after being hunted by everyone from there. You found out father-mother biggest darkest secret and now in fear of your life. With your girlfriend Deadra you both leave the village to trivial to the end of the world to find answers.

The story has a great build up. It makes you want to know whats going to happen, why you are being hunted, and what is this BIG secret that ghat know. However when it's finally revealed what it is, you kinda feel disappointed. You have this great build up of a story to be let down at the end.

Graphics: 9

The graphics really sets the mood. Each level you go to has it's over style and feel to it. The last level you where just in doesn't look like the one your current in. Each level feels different and fresh while keeping to the primal cave man feel of the game. The graphics are all over the place from bright looking to dark. Some how it all works out nicely. You get a real sense of this world.

To be honest, the world to me feels like Alice in wonderland but cave man style. You have such a massive world with crazy looking characters from humans, to animals, to each scene. The graphics really sets this game up nicely. I can not express how much I love the graphics for this game and just how it all comes together to make this world. It's a pretty unique experience. To me this what really makes game shine the most.

Music: 8

The music does a good job keeping pace with whats going on. It helps to make the world to come alive with the background ambiance. The music does a great job to set each level up and keep it feeling unique as much as possible.

Final Though:

Even though the game play is like a lot of other shooters with some added melee. This game just shines when it comes to presentation of the world. You will find your self lost in this crazy mystical world. Wanting to see more of what this world has to offer. I was so immersed in the world alone just because how it looked and felt and with all the crazy characters you end up meeting just really pulls it together to make it feel so unique. I compare this world of alice in wonder land, though not as amazing as alice but it has the great mystical feel to it that keep you wanting more.

However like I said before it kinda of falls off the story with a great build up with a disappointing ending. However the ending is better than some other games out there.

I find this game a good game to play for any one who like first person shooters. However this game IS weird and odd. If you can't get behind outlandish things you may find your self not liking this game.

I sat down and beat this game in one sitting. Took me roughly 6 hours to beat it. So over all I would recommend this most to most people.

Also...mother ♥♥♥♥ing Squirrels with mother ♥♥♥♥ing bombs strapped to there mother ♥♥♥♥ing backs!

Final Score: 8

for more reviews and other fun things check out my tumblr. www.rogue32807.tumblr.com

reviewText:
In Zeno Clash, you play as Ghat who is part of a 'family' by this strange creature known as Father-Mother. During the beginning of the game, things won't be very clear except that the supposed brothers and sisters that are a part of this family accuse you of killing Father-Mother. More is revealed as you progress in the game and you eventually find out the truth. Personally, I won't go into further details about the story to avoid spoilers.

The gameplay is very unique in such a way that you don't often see this genre...This game plays in a first person perspective but your use of combat isn't through weapons (there is ranged weapons in the game, but you won't always be using them) instead, you use your fists to beat the ever living crap out of whoever stands in your way. You can lock on to your enemies and switch between which can be handy for quickly knowing when to defend or attack. At some areas of the game, your fists alone won't be reliable enough to hurt some enemies as some of them can vary from big enemies who charge at you and can knock you over resulting in some nasty damage or you have creatures that spit crap at you. So what do you do when it comes down to that? You use weapons! You can pick up some unique looking weapons that help from dual welded bone like pistols to a crossbow that fires skulls that explode upon impact with your enemies or you can have a bone sledgehammer that can deal massive damage to your enemies as you charge your swing.

The level design is incredibly trippy but that's likely what the developers were going for as the world of Zeno Clash is incredibly unreal and is full of plenty of strange yet pretty scenary.

Zeno Clash also has a unique tower mode which you unlock levels of as you progress through the main story. In the tower mode, you are inside a tower killing every enemy in the room to progress higher into the tower and you also also put against a time which shows how long you take. The timer isn't all too important as its just to put you against your friends to see who's faster at the level. As you progress, you'll meet all the different enemies you have met throughout the main game and in some rooms, you will have weapons that you can use or disarm from your enemies. But in the later levels there will also be room hazards that can be useful for killing your enemies in one fell swoop but be careful! As if you aren't, you can also be killed quickly.

All in all, Zeno Clash is a incredibly fun game where you beat the crap out of people and I recommend checking it out if you're looking to punch in some faces! Plus, if you buy it and own Garry's Mod, you'll get all the models from the game!

reviewText:
Zeno Clash is strange. There it is. I said it. You're totally surprised.

Not only is it strange, but it's awkward. Honestly I couldn't tell if I was enjoying it until I completed it in one night. The concept is great. The melee combat is innovative and challenging. The story is so different that you'll spend most of the game being confused and wanting to know more.

The story is one thing, but the scenery is astounding. It's like being shoved into someone's nightmare and battling disfigured humanoids and being afraid of the environment. I see 'Surreal' in the game tags now, which hits the nail on the head.

Zeno clash is all over the place with the scenes that take place. I don't want to get into details - mostly since it's been a bit since I've played it and don't want to be 'that jackass', but the story is pretty much the entire game to me. I can't go around spouting out spoilers, right? ;b

reviewText: My experience with Zeno Clash was really strange. When I started, almost from very beggining I was put in fight, after two or three fights I closed game. I was wondering, when I will play it again. Combat system in Zeno Clash isn't bad - it's fine but also very annoying. I can't count how many times I got attacked from behind, but that's not what was annoying, the thing that comes after - not sure if it's bug, or if it should work that way, but almost everytime my character was performing once again last action. If fighting, in this kind of game, doesn't bring much pleasure then what is point of playing? This is easy question - THE WORLD AND CHARACTERS LIVING IN IT. This is most interesting part of game. I love every place and character this game have. With every next hour I wanted to know more. I would really love to see Zeno Clash as adventure game. I know I would have much more fun exploring new places, talking around and such than fighting. Well, that's just my opinion. If you love exploring bizzare worlds - Zeno Clash is good for that. Still, there is plenty of fighting, which can be hit or miss in case of Zeno Clash. In my case, it was sadly a miss.

First person action/melee brawler in which you are one of the many children of Father-Mother and the only to know his dark secret. You must fight your brothers and sisters on your journey to confront Father-Mother. The story unfolds through cutscenes and flashbacks and is really eccentric. The areas and transitions feel quite disconnected initially, but near the end it starts coming together, things get interesting and the ending is satisfying.

The combat isn't simple or intuitive and it'll take you a long time to learn advanced moves like dodging and countering attacks. Even the easiest difficulty will be frustrating if you don't master this system, so there is some skill involved.

The game looks great with nice art, but the soundtrack is mediocre. It's short, lasting only a few hours if you don't try for achievements or challenge modes. There isn't a lot of depth here: no stats or inventory, it's 100% linear/combat and not much enemy or weapon variation, but still a good game.

One of the better and more interesting Indie games I've played. Powered on the source engine with some pretty fantastic visuals, well it's a fighting game with some weapons thrown into it.\n\nIt's got a pretty good campaign, Zeno Clash is worth a try.

A true hidden gem that deserves so much more recognition. I haven't seen such hauntingly alien landscapes and settings since Morrowind, the visual desing in this game is excellent with every location being memorable and every character becoming quickly recognizable at a glance. The combat is fresh, easy to learn but difficult to master and very satisfying which is amazing when you consider this is a first person fighting game! Even the plot feels like something vibrant and different, while fairly simple and some what predictable, you are presented with a rich and detailed world that oozes life and history but never feels the need to bog things down explaining itself.

The closest thing I can think of to bring up as criticism is that the sound design is very lacking, the music is so forgettable that it may as well not be there and the voice actors seem strictly amateur. It's also very short, there is some replay value with multiple endings and a challenge mode but it's still only a few afternoons worth of play. These are however very minor flaws in an otherwise beautiful game.

At the price this goes for during sales you owe it to yourself to experience this.

First person action/melee brawler in which you are one of the many children of Father-Mother and the only to know his dark secret. You must fight your brothers and sisters on your journey to confront Father-Mother. The story unfolds through cutscenes and flashbacks and is really eccentric. The areas and transitions feel quite disconnected initially, but near the end it starts coming together, things get interesting and the ending is satisfying.

The combat isn't simple or intuitive and it'll take you a long time to learn advanced moves like dodging and countering attacks. Even the easiest difficulty will be frustrating if you don't master this system, so there is some skill involved.

The game looks great with nice art, but the soundtrack is mediocre. It's short, lasting only a few hours if you don't try for achievements or challenge modes. There isn't a lot of depth here: no stats or inventory, it's 100% linear/combat and not much enemy or weapon variation, but still a good game.

A loose connection of small corridors that are unreasonably padded with ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Oh yes, it's not only a first-person punch-'em-up, it also throws in wildlife for you to shoot with guns that deal small amounts of damage while taking their time to reload. If you thought you could punch the buggers with your mighty fists, think again: they spawn behind the walls of the level, so shoot away, chum.\n\nFirst-person fighting is rare in video games, and it's rare for a reason. If you're fighting more than one enemy at a time, which is always, you are bound to get blindsided and be interrupted mid-combo. You could keep your distance, keep everyone in your sights, use satisfyingly powerful melee weapons and win the encounter unscratched. Or you could not play this game and ultimately have a better time.
Cronenberg meets Fight Club. You'll either love it or hate it. Watch some gameplay videos before buying.

What is this, I don't even..

One of the more genuinely strange games I've ever played--made all the more strange by the fact that it doesn't seem to be cribbing from any familiar sources (at least that I am aware of) to construct its game world. You play a guy who is cast out of his tribe after murdering your hermaphroditic Father/Mother under mysterious circumstances. As the game progresses you piece together the events leading up to the murder all while evading your siblings who are out for vengeance.\n\nOh yeah, and it's also a first person beat em up. Despite being such a potentially disastrous genre hybrid (FPS fighting games have rarely worked) the fighting mechanics and controls are actually implemented fairly well. Likewise, the art direction is top notch. Ultimately the central game mechanics are a bit limited, but the game is smart enough to be brief, ending just before you start to get bored with things. I probably prefer Rock of Ages" (by the same team)
date: but this is a worthy first game from them."

reviewText:
I think that Zeno Clash is worth playing, especially for the ridiculously low prices for which it can be purchased during sales.

The combat is interesting and varied up until you are required to apply the same mêlée combat techniques to the majority of enemy types. There are more than 10 different fighting moves, without regard for any of the hand-held weapons, but with time you will find certain combinations to be most effective.
During a one-on-one fight you can easily achieve a nice, powerful rhythm - however, when there are many enemies it can be difficult to single one out to focus your efforts.
For less gung-ho players this may result in the tiresome process of wearing multiple enemies down one jab at a time. Drop a grenade amongst foes to speed things up.

From this you may infer that too much of one thing can become dull, so luckily this tedium is broken up by special enemies that require more than fisticuffs.
For example, heavy-set enemies can be overcome by using evasion or timed attacks to bring them to a state of vulnerability. Large, mentally-unstable enemies' weaknesses must be exploited to bring them down to your level so that you may cure their neurosis with, you guessed it, more punching.
This does something to alleviate the familiarity of the dodge-punch-block-kick reptition of fighting, though these types of enemies are, too, used repeatedly.

Sore knuckles and noses is not the only draw card for Zeno Clash, and if you aren't going to play for the combat then please play this game for the fantastic artistic design - for the music, visual art and script.
I found the surreal landscapes and the outlandish flora and fauna to be both beautiful and unsettling. The ramshackle settlements and deformed, (often literally) animalistic citizens had me yearning to see what grotesqueries would arise next and I found this incredibly engaging for the duration of the game. The voices are many and varied, highly emotive and serve to easily differentiate the actors and how they feel towards the protagonist - as well as showing their individual strengths and weaknesses of character.

If you appreciate well-executed gameplay and beautiful art direction then I believe that you will enjoy Zeno Clash as much as I did.
If you have played it already then I urge you to buy it for a friend who has missed out.

I wanted to wait until I finished everything in Zeno Clash before I wrote a review on it.

I like this game a lot. It has such a weired origonal setting full of interesting characters. The story can be a bit confusing but is overall its pretty good. In terms of gameplay the story is rather short but there are challenge levels afterwards that are fairly difficult and will take time and skill to complete.

Gameplay wise the combat system is fairly simple and somewhat repeteive but very entertaining. The game consists of several martial arts battle with one to several opponents.

The only real complaint I have with the game is that the controller support is terrible and I could not get it to work with my 360 controller well enough to use it. With that being sade the game plays just fine with a mouse and keyboard.

Overall I would give it a 7.5/10 well executed with some noticable flaws.

reviewText:
TL;DR – The most this caveman brawler gives you in terms of plot and setting exposition is a moderately-short blurb on the game’s store page. Also, one of the enemy models closely resembles a *ToTaLLy MEtAl* version of the Swedish Chef from “The Muppet Show”. Recommend.

Onto the review:

It’s actually to Zeno Clash’s benefit that it doesn’t really explain itself outside of the basic gameplay mechanics, which are simplistic but nevertheless require a bit of finesse if you’re playing on any of the higher difficulties. To elaborate, combat is your typical mouse-bound primary-light-attack, secondary-heavy-attack affair, utilizing the spacebar for blocking and evading. Uncoordinated lout that I am, this was interpreted as “spam the secondary/primary and run around like a chicken sans head”. This style" of gameplay actually worked for me
date: thanks to the normal-level difficulty setting I was playing on
recommended: in addition to smartly-placed health items in each area.\n\nUnfortunately
hoursPlayed: this is also the likely cause of the game’s growing tediousness later on
helpfulPercent: outside of a few close calls and even some deaths

votesFunny: a brawling sequence being followed by a shooting gallery level

column16: oh the guns.\n\nIndeed
column17: the weapons in Zeno Clash most succinctly sum up the game’s overall art aesthetic; the closest comparison in décor is that of “The Flintstones”
column18: with its brightly-colored yet naturalistic designs. Hell
column19: there’s even dinosaurs (or at least large reptiles resembling them) in a level or two. The guns themselves specifically piqued my interest
column20: as the idea of a primeval-era slugthrower is just surreally fantastic. For example
column22: which basically appear to be carved shells with a bunch of nails and rocks stuffed into them
column23: are just fun to look at and use in all of their pea-shootery goodness (which may also explain why I keep running into the same named characters again after I so thoroughly obliterate their asses).\n\nBesides the art design
column24: this sense of backwards absurdity is ingrained in the plot and characters; outside of the aftermentioned blurb

reviewText:
One of my first purchases here on Steam. I believe it was back in 2009 if I remember correctly and it did have a very nice discount on it so it was immediately in my basket.

Zeno Clash is an ambitious first person shooter game developed by ACE Team and released in 2009. The game uses the modified version of the Source Engine so it runs very well and while it is somewhat of an aged engine it still - in my opinion - looks good.

Interestingly, rarely do you have the chance to use weapons with projectiles; emphasis is on melee combat and you do have the chance to use some clubs or other heavy weapons beside your fists. Combat is simple but very smooth - the game is very linear and as it is an independent game you can already guess it is quite short.

Story-wise the game is rather silly - it puts you in the shoes of Ghat who is banished from his home after an attempt to kill Father-Mother. Yes, this creature is his father and mother as it seems the entire population of Ghat's settlement was raised by this hermaphroditic creature. Although banished, Ghat wishes to uncover the truth as to what really happened and what secret lies with the family.

Anyways, combat is quite good and the game has a challenge option with levels of a tower to compete against a series of enemies. This is getting difficult gradually - a nice way to pass time once the story mode is finished.

Zeno Clash is somewhat mediocre, but I believe the result of an original idea. If it is on sale this is a highly recommended game.

reviewText: Twice I have tried desperately to play this game under the constant peer pressure of It's so quirky but a fun beat 'em up! PLAY IT! PLAY IT YOU ♥♥♥♥!". Now I concede: I really hate this game and never want to play it again.\n\nYes the design and aesthetics are quirky as all hell
date: as are the story and dialogue. I actually love that about Zeno Clash; it's like a weird off-cut of early 2000's forays into 3D alien architecture that takes cues from someone who spent too much time flipping through microbiology books.\n\nOn the surface the controls aren't difficult and combat seems manageable
recommended: if a little grating at times. I hate blocking mechanics even moreso when your dodge or evasion system is tied to it with movement. Using weapons is a pain in the ♥♥♥ because you can't dodge with a weapon and if you're not quite in range you start kicking insead of swinging your weapon. Also it won't let me use a controller which is god damn insane. The only thing I like about the combat is how visceral and meaty it can feel at times
hoursPlayed: when it isn't completely disorienting and aggravating.\n\nBut perhaps all these problems are solely on me
voteText: and my desire for a dodge roll button or a lock-on system with a smoother option to switch between targets is an admission of weakness? I really wanted to like Zeno Clash but god help me the combat is really awful and controls like ♥♥♥♥. Maybe the sequel magically fixes everything? I don't know and I don't care to find out.\n\nTry to get it on sale or in a bundle

reviewText:
This is easily the worst game I've ever played...ever.

The whole entire game feels like it was created by a team of people who have never played a game before, or at least a good one. The lock on system is atrocious. You're stuck fighting one guy while three other enemies are all taking swings at you that you can't see coming, nor block. You're fighting the combat/lock on system more then you're fighting enemies. Also you get a power attack (right click) but don't even bother with it since the enemies ALWAYS dodge it so it's useless.

The boss' in this game are laughable. I beat most of them by punching then running. Stick and move, there's no variation.

The story is just trying to hard to be different, or abstract but it's neither. It's like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Oddworld without any substance.

The graphics look like they were thrown together hastily. It's just a complete package of dumb. The worst game ever, and the sad part is it has a sequel. Anachronox has no sequel, Beyond Good and Evil has no sequel but THIS game has a sequel.

reviewText: There's a good game buried somewhere in here. The mechanics are great and the combat seems like what Dead Island was trying to achieve. Sadly the art director from this project was given nothing but a box of crayons and apparently M. Knight Shyamalan was hired to write what this game laughably calls a story. This is the single most unpleasant game to look at I've ever played. The scaling is awful and every character has hit the lowest point of the uncanny valley. Nearly everything is this game is unsettling to look at which would be great for a horror game but definitely not here. Zeno Clash proudly wears its pretentious art house mask, but unlike Braid, doesn't have the engaging story or gorgeous visuals to back it up.

reviewText:
Here's a game you should definitely try! It's both great and well... incredibly average, but it's satisfying from start to finish.
This is a short game, you can easily complete it in about 3 hours. It's a kinda sloppy melee first-person brawler.  Its combat system isn't bad, but it gets clunky at times, specially in group fights. However, punching enemies into a 5 meter flight makes you feel like a badass. And the ragdoll physics on the corpses are a nice touch as well.
I haven't played Zeno Clash 2 yet, but I will soon enough, and I assume the combat system has been polished since 2009, although I've heard it focus too much on team fights, which is where the clumsiness comes in... But I digress.

The game shines in its world and characters, which are all really weird, but at the same time, charming. They present neat ideas that feel like they should have been much more explored and fleshed out, but everything seems experimental here, hence its length.

reviewText:
Oh, beautiful Zeno Clash..
Zeno Clash is probably the only First Person Brawler in existance, and it does it oh so well. Instead of holding a gun, you have fists, and those fists hammer into enemies' faces ruthlessly. There are grabs, palm strikes, kicks, parries.. finishing moves.. Oh, and also guns, though you rarely get the chance to use them. The game has quite a high learning curve, but as soon as you get it down, I've found that it is one of the more enjoyable combat systems I have had the pleasure of playing with.

The world of Zeno Clash is also vibrant and full of unique characters. The one who struck me the most were the Corwid of the Free, who are all obviously clinically insane in their single-mindedness. They do things because they do them. Examples being that one only wanted to walk in a straight line, another only wanted to eat people because that's what he did, and another wanted to be invisible, so he removed the eyes over everything that could see him, including his own. The art department really outdid itself on character design, and there isn't a single character in the game that could be classified as 'bland'

The game also features an arena mode, which is probably best played after a first playthrough to get the basics down.

All in all, this game was worth every cent. Get it if you want something new (and disturbing)!

reviewText:
I have a love-hate relationship with this game. The story was pretty mediocre, but they constantly pull you along with the promise of this huge secret right around every corner. So I was constantly driven to play to figure it out, thinking I was getting closer and closer. Near the end you can figure it out and it’s honestly quite a letdown. The world is interesting and unique, but none of the characters are fleshed out enough for you to really care for them. I have to imagine they had an amazing world in-mind, but were limited in how they could present it. Still there’s plenty of mystery and yearning to find out more.

The gameplay is fluid and has some fun melee components. It's unique in how the game almost plays out like an arena/fighter and FPS game. I had some issues with the controls, like accidently throwing my gun around into unobtainable places, but all in all the combat remained challenging (but not frustratingly so) and never dull.

Regardless of the game's flaws, I can't deny how enthralled I was in the game within the short time it took me to beat it. I would recommend this game to any fans of parachuting squirrels, punching people in the face and mystery.

reviewText:
Unique is the name of the game here.

It's an interesting experience but not very polished.

The fighting system is a first person brawler, but uses fighting game mechanics so it's a really unique combat system that unfortunately doesn't work all that well. It's simple  to fight a small number of enemies once you get the hang of it, but late in the game you have to fight large numbers of enemies with varying abilities, and ranged attacks, making it incredibly difficult to keep track of everything and ramping up the difficulty.

The story is unique as well, you play as an exiled prince sort of character, but beyond that, absolutely nothing makes sense. I'll use my Psych degree and says this whole thing carries a lot of Jungian and Freudian overtones as well.

The voice acting, is god awful.

If you're looking for a unique game experience, something you haven't seen before, this is it, if you're worried about the unpolished nature, better avoid.

reviewText: Really not worth your time.\nThe idea is great, but in execution not at all. Pair this with an unbelievable story, extremely weird world design with nothing to like about and sub-par voice acting, this game was a real pain to get through. reviewText: Not really sure what I expected with this game. It's clever and 100% original, I'll give it that. Also, you'll probably never see or play another game like it, that's for sure (except for Zeno Clash 2). But it's not really fun. I mean, the first hour is interesting because it's a new game and you're probably wondering why the game is so bizarre but I said it was clever because what sucks you in is the story and the strange events that take place within this game. Not much else. The fighting mechanic is interesting, but it's more of a gimmick than anything else. Take away all the zanny stuff in this game and you're left with a very VERY poor FPS-brawler. Still, very much recommended! Perhaps Zeno Clash 2 is an improvement?

reviewText: The world of Zenozoik is strange, dirty, and down right alien at times. The character and terrain designs oscillate between beautifully surreal and head-scratchingly mismatched. Everything you see is a wonder to behold and, however improbable, feels as if it belongs there, feels alive. Following Ghat around as he tells his tale and very slowly reveals what he knows was thrilling. No matter how many times he refused to say more, I didn't feel like I was being stalled because it was clear how deeply the secret affected him. His character was fully formed and relatable. But the ending itself felt rushed and not quite as climactic as it seemed to think it was. The big reveal was satisfying, it was the lack of answers pertaining to the newer character that the conclusion centered around that made it somewhat hollow.  If said character was not introduced and the plot remained focused on the conflict between Ghat and Father-mother, I would have no complaints about the storyline. The combat, however, has some issues. Combat is the bulk of game and it never feels quite right. The sights and sounds seem right, when a blow connects there's good feedback, but I never could tell what was and was not going to hit me. The enemies will become invincible at times, during charge up attacks and after being knocked down, which doesn't go along with how the combat itself is presented. There's also not a whole lot to the combat which is a blessing at first, but causes it all to become repetitive later on. In the end, none of that is going to stop me from playing the sequel when the mood hits me, but I'm not exactly rushing into either.

reviewText:
I don't know why this game get so much hype. Maybe it was OK for 2009, maybe. I got this on a bundle and have been determined to beat it more than once. The problem is its boring. The story is not engaging, the voice acting is awful, and the combat is clunky. As far as I can tell this game was only rated so high because of its wacky visuals. Woo.

This is a point to point brawler. You walk some you fight some dudes. You walk some more you fight some more dudes. There are no alternate paths to explore and there will be invisible walls stopping you at every turn. Intermixed with the fighting and walking are cut scenes". In these the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ voice actors force out their bizarre dialog in such a way you can tell they are confused by what they are saying.

The combat is crap. Step forward a little and punch. Either a 3 punch combo by holding left mouse or a strong attack on right mouse. There is also a dodge by pressing space bar and an arrow key while locked into melee. I never found a use for it though. Sure it gives you a chance to counter but it was hard to time right. It was much easier to take a step back
date: wait for the attack animation to end then walk back up and spam mouse one holds. This tactic works on every character until the end of the game. Trying to use strong attack pretty much always resulted in me getting hit before my attack would launch. Now don't let this make you think I had difficulty with this
recommended: I was owning every boring clunky fight. They added some additional fight mechanics towards the end of the game. I don't remember what they were though because I didn't use them.\n\nI eventually just gave up my quest to beat this ♥♥♥♥ game at the end. I beat the first round of guys easily taking minimal damage. The problem was the two guys on the roof shooting me with crossbows. All I could fight back with was a wildly inaccurate grenade launcher. I tried to lob a couple grenades up at them but the just picked me off easily with shot after shot of highly damaging
voteText: homing cross bow shot. I tried to dodge and lob another grenade. Only to watch the ♥♥♥♥ing cross bow bolt follow me and hit me.\n\nThis is where I gave up. This game isn't worth it

reviewText: Zeno Clash is Double Dragon and Streets of Rage, but 3D and in the first person. It's weird and cool to use those same strategies from a different viewpoint. Still, don't mistake this for an adventure: it's a fighter, and if you aren't good at them or aren't into them, you're going to have a rough time. Thankfully each battle plays out as a chapter
date: so you don't have to worry about losing progress, you can pick whatever chapter you want to play.

reviewText: The game was ok, it had it's moments of fun but in the end the combat is to sticky, the story is really non-existant and you figure out the plot twist about 15 minutes into the game and then spend the rest of the game grinding through combat that gets harder and harder. Normally I would say that combat getting harder is a good thing, but in this case they make it harder by adding more enemies into each fight, the designers knew that their really clunky combat system does badly with multiple enemies, its really easy to get trapped in a corner and beaten while someone shoots you from a distance. I finished the game in under 4 hours and about 30% of that time I was trying to make the combat system work smoothly, I dislike broken combat a great deal. Probably an hour or more of the game is taken up with just sitting there and barely doing anything. It tried to be different and it almost succeeded. In the end, I don't think its worth even $10, maybe $5 or throw it in for free with some other game.
